Harvard critic gets a taste of her own plagiarism medicine







Thread starter
Davocrat




Start date
Jan 5, 2024

2

3

Davocrat




Joined Apr 2007

114K Posts | 151K+

Ilkville













 Discussion Starter



Jan 5, 2024













#1









First of all, I am only commenting about the charges of plagiarism against ex-president Gay.



As another member here pointed out, if you look closely enough at any academic writing, it's not hard to find "violations" of citation standards. And if you're a reactionary scrutinizing a short haired African American woman with big glasses, you're going to REALLY scrutinize her papers.



Careful though. What goes around comes around.










Neri Oxman, billionaire investor Bill Ackman’s wife, accused of plagiarism in MIT dissertation



Ackman has been a vocal critic of Harvard’s recently-resigned president, Claudine Gay, over allegations of plagiarism and her handling of antisemitism.





www.nbcnews.com

Jan 5, 2024













#2









AI tools are already advanced enough to be able to find countless examples of plagiarism that human peer review almost certainly couldn't have back when the research was published.



Authors and researchers with lots of published work out there should be trying to get out ahead of this, go back and check their past work before others decide to go out and find it and weaponize it against them.



The future of intellectual property and copyright and whatnot is going to be pretty interesting.

Watertown, MA















Jan 5, 2024













#3









The guy behind the attacks on Gay was our old buddy, Chris Rufo. Yeah, that liar. His real interest is not in academic perfection:






"We must not stop until we have abolished DEI ideology from every institution in America," he said in one post on X, formerly Twitter. In another post, he announced a new "plagiarism hunting fund," pledging to "expose the rot in the Ivy League and restore truth, rather than racialist ideology, as the highest principle in academic life."

https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/neil-gorsuch-under-pressure-over-plagiarism-allegations/ar-AA1mtcaE?ocid=msedgntp&pc=EDGEDSE&cvid=aac450aa741d4f898839d2a43aaab70a&ei=27


Click to expand...





Surprise! It was all about race, after all. Gosh, who knew? But now that the right-wingers have pledged to rid the world of even inadvertent "under-citation" I assume they're going to be badgering this guy to resign, too:






After Harvard University President Claudine Gay's career came under the spotlight, forcing her resignation after a series of plagiarism allegations, some are calling for U.S. Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch to face similar scrutiny...[based on] a 2017 report by Politico that accused the justice of plagiarism before he was appointed to the high court. The report said documents show that several passages from a chapter of Gorsuch's 2006 book, The Future of Assisted Suicide and Euthanasia, read "nearly verbatim" to a 1984 article in the Indiana Law Journal. The report also said that in several other instances in that book and an academic article published in 2000, Gorsuch "borrowed from the ideas, quotes and structures of scholarly and legal works without citing them."


Click to expand...

Further, in the particular instance of Harvard, one of the best institutions in the world, where a policy exists to an exacting standard with regards to plagiarism, why is it that in this instance it should devolve to race, whereas theinstitution itself manages instances like this irrespective of same???

#6









The Harvard President had plagiarism prevalent in a ton of her "work". In some instances, she ripped of mass amounts from other scholars and authors. This is not the same.



Gay is guilty of the charges of which she has been accused. The Left Cult defend her not because she is right, but because those pointing out she's a scumbag are conservatives. The Left has no integrity on this issue and now they want to cast stone at others when they refused to deal with Gay?

#9











Davocrat said:




Careful though. What goes around comes around.


Click to expand...





I suspect that accusing the wife of the guy that had issues with Gay is just some very lame attempt to punish people that call out the idiocy of DEI. But, here is her response on X. Whether you accept her response as legitimate or not, this is the type of response one would give if they believed they are being wrongly accused. She goes into detail of every assertion and addresses them one by one. Has anyone seen anything like this from Gay? So far, all I have seen is chants of "racist". 



--------



I was forwarded an email this morning from a reporter at Business Insider who noted that there are four paragraphs in my 330-page PhD dissertation: “Material-based Design Computation,” which I completed at 

@MIT

in 2010,https://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/59192#:~:text=Material%2Dbased%20Design%20Computation%20is,with%20digital%20analysis%20and%20fabrication...where I omitted quotation marks for certain work that I used. For each of the four paragraphs in question, I properly credited the original source's author(s) with references at the end of each of the subject paragraphs, and in the detailed bibliography end pages of the dissertation. In these four paragraphs, however, I did not place the subject language in quotation marks, which would be the proper approach for crediting the work. I regret and apologize for these errors.Business Insider also identified one sentence in the dissertation where I paraphrased Claus Mattheck and did not cite him:“The range of loads to which a tree is exposed is vast and it includes forces of various magnitudes and directions, bending moments, torsional moments, and thermal stresses amongst others. If the tree is to resist the loads exerted upon it, these loads must be countered by a support applying equally large, but opposed, reaction loads against it.” (Oxman, p. 49)Compare with Mattheck:“The multiplicity of external loads to which a tree component can be exposed can be divided into forces, bending moments, torsional moments and thermal stresses. If the component is not to be moved, these loads must be countered by a support exerting equally large but opposed reaction loads.”I should have provided a citation to Mattheck for the above sentence. I paraphrased from his book, “Design in nature: learning from trees, Springer 1998,” which I cited throughout my thesis, and properly attributed in the sections which follow the subject sentence. I deeply apologize to Mattheck for inadvertently not citing him when I paraphrased the above sentence.I am grateful for Mattheck’s contribution to the field as I noted in the dissertation in a section entitled “Background and Reference” on page 114:“Similar advancements in optimization have been developed in the field of Biomimetics as engineers reveal Nature’s unique capacities for the design and optimization of its products. Within this scope, significant work has been carried out by Prof. Claus Mattheck, director of the Research Center at Karlsruhe. Mattheck embarked on the mission of simulating knot healing processes in trees. Knots are usually attributed to dormant buds or cut side branches and are generally considered as imperfections in the wood which greatly affect its mechanical properties. Taking an in inspiration from Nature, Mattheck’s aim was to develop processes to mimic growth and refinement and further implement them as computational routines in the field of shape optimization.”For one of the four paragraphs in question, Business Insider claims that I incorrectly attributed the cited paragraph to two papers by different authors: “Vincent, J. F. V., Structural biomaterials,” Macmillan, London, 1982 and Vogel, S., “Comparative biomechanics: life’s physical world,” Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ. 2003.Business Insider claims the proper source for this paragraph is: "The mechanical properties of natural materials," by Michael Farries Ashby, L. J. Gibson, U Wegst and R Olive, published in 1995 in the Proceedings of the Royal Society of London.Ashby et al also cite Vincent and Vogel in their introductory paragraph just prior to the paragraph in question, as well as in their bibliography. I believe, therefore, that Ashby may also be using Vincent and Vogel in the paragraph in question, but clearly, since one of the sources I cite is from Vogel 2003, there is a problem with the citation.Unfortunately, because some of the original sources are not online, and Business Insider was unwilling to give me beyond 4pm to review these citations, I cannot confirm whether Business Insider or the sources I referenced for this paragraph are correct.When I obtain access to the original sources, I will check all of the above citations and request that MIT make any necessary corrections.As I have dedicated my career to advancing science and innovation, I have always recognized the profound importance of the contributions of my peers and those who came before me. I hope that my work is helpful to the generations to come.I am also incredibly grateful for the 15 years I spent at MIT beginning when I enrolled in the PhD program in 2005, obtained my PhD in 2010, and later joined the faculty that same year. I became a tenured member of the faculty in 2017 and then left MIT in 2020 after I got married, became a mother, and moved to New York City.I have continued my work in a new company I founded in New York City called OXMAN, which along with 27 other members of my team, we are working to advance innovation in product, architectural, and urban design. OXMAN has been in stealth mode. I look forward to sharing more about OXMAN later this year.

I hope that my work is helpful to the generations to come.I am also incredibly grateful for the 15 years I spent at MIT beginning when I enrolled in the PhD program in 2005, obtained my PhD in 2010, and later joined the faculty that same year. I became a tenured member of the faculty in 2017 and then left MIT in 2020 after I got married, became a mother, and moved to New York City.I have continued my work in a new company I founded in New York City called OXMAN, which along with 27 other members of my team, we are working to advance innovation in product, architectural, and urban design. OXMAN has been in stealth mode. I look forward to sharing more about OXMAN later this year.

Sure hope nobody checks all my old writing.

#15











Philfish said:




is this intentionally race baiting, or do you think plagiarism can safely be scrutinized regardless of color, gender, etc? Further, in the particular instance of Harvard, one of the best institutions in the world, where a policy exists to an exacting standard with regards to plagiarism, why is it that in this instance it should devolve to race, whereas theinstitution itself manages instances like this irrespective of same???


Click to expand...





Phil, I think I made a pretty reasonable post, but I guess somewhere along the line I pissed you off, so you are doomed to "bust Davocrat's balls" for eternity.



There's nothing "race baiting" about anything in what I said. You sound like @Crusher, who always suspects Black people whose skills are challenged.



If Gay made statements that were offensive to Jews, she deserves harsh critique. But my point here is, if you scrutinize every academic's papers you're not unlikely to find errors. And a quotation mark can technically make you a plagiarist of something that really does nothing to make your argument stronger or it could fundamentally change your treatise.



My OP presents one quick example and it's an example made of a person who critiqued Gay's work. And just one article. I bet you could find more in other stuff.



BTW, noticed how @Crusher uses scare quotes on "work," as if to suggest that Gay does inferior work. It's not race baiting to suggest that Crusher is prejudiced here, because he never "finds" for the Black person. EVER.

#16









I'm sure I have mistakenly forgotten to add quotes here when I post the words of others, but I try to make an effort.

If we were to check whether there are adequate citations among all postings here, what would we find, from whom?



Yes, plagiarism is a real thing, but it should not be a political thing, which some have turned it into, for the mere fact that it is bound to backfire upon them, as we have already seen.

Harvard critic gets a taste of her own plagiarism medicine

    Discussion Starter

  • #1
First of all, I am only commenting about the charges of plagiarism against ex-president Gay.

As another member here pointed out, if you look closely enough at any academic writing, it's not hard to find "violations" of citation standards. And if you're a reactionary scrutinizing a short haired African American woman with big glasses, you're going to REALLY scrutinize her papers.

Careful though. What goes around comes around.

Neri Oxman, billionaire investor Bill Ackman’s wife, accused of plagiarism in MIT dissertation

Ackman has been a vocal critic of Harvard’s recently-resigned president, Claudine Gay, over allegations of plagiarism and her handling of antisemitism.
www.nbcnews.com

AI tools are already advanced enough to be able to find countless examples of plagiarism that human peer review almost certainly couldn't have back when the research was published.

Authors and researchers with lots of published work out there should be trying to get out ahead of this, go back and check their past work before others decide to go out and find it and weaponize it against them.

The future of intellectual property and copyright and whatnot is going to be pretty interesting.

The guy behind the attacks on Gay was our old buddy, Chris Rufo. Yeah, that liar. His real interest is not in academic perfection:

"We must not stop until we have abolished DEI ideology from every institution in America," he said in one post on X, formerly Twitter. In another post, he announced a new "plagiarism hunting fund," pledging to "expose the rot in the Ivy League and restore truth, rather than racialist ideology, as the highest principle in academic life."

After Harvard University President Claudine Gay's career came under the spotlight, forcing her resignation after a series of plagiarism allegations, some are calling for U.S. Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch to face similar scrutiny...[based on] a 2017 report by Politico that accused the justice of plagiarism before he was appointed to the high court. I suspect that accusing the wife of the guy that had issues with Gay is just some very lame attempt to punish people that call out the idiocy of DEI. But, here is her response on X. Whether you accept her response as legitimate or not, this is the type of response one would give if they believed they are being wrongly accused. She goes into detail of every assertion and addresses them one by one. Has anyone seen anything like this from Gay? So far, all I have seen is chants of "racist".

--------

I was forwarded an email this morning from a reporter at Business Insider who noted that there are four paragraphs in my 330-page PhD dissertation: “Material-based Design Computation,” which I completed at
@MIT
in 2010,https://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/59192#:~:text=Material%2Dbased%20Design%20Computation%20is,with%20digital%20analysis%20and%20fabrication...where I omitted quotation marks for certain work that I used. For each of the four paragraphs in question, I properly credited the original source's author(s) with references at the end of each of the subject paragraphs, and in the detailed bibliography end pages of the dissertation. In these four paragraphs, however, I did not place the subject language in quotation marks, which would be the proper approach for crediting the work. I regret and apologize for these errors.Business Insider also identified one sentence in the dissertation where I paraphrased Claus Mattheck and did not cite him:“The range of loads to which a tree is exposed is vast and it includes forces of various magnitudes and directions, bending moments, torsional moments, and thermal stresses amongst others. If the tree is to resist the loads exerted upon it, these loads must be countered by a support applying equally large, but opposed, reaction loads against it.” (Oxman, p. 49)Compare with Mattheck:“The multiplicity of external loads to which a tree component can be exposed can be divided into forces, bending moments, torsional moments and thermal stresses. If the component is not to be moved, these loads must be countered by a support exerting equally large but opposed reaction loads.”I should have provided a citation to Mattheck for the above sentence. I paraphrased from his book, “Design in nature: learning from trees, Springer 1998,” which I cited throughout my thesis, and properly attributed in the sections which follow the subject sentence. I deeply apologize to Mattheck for inadvertently not citing him when I paraphrased the above sentence.I am grateful for Mattheck’s contribution to the field as I noted in the dissertation in a section entitled “Background and Reference” on page 114:“Similar advancements in optimization have been developed in the field of Biomimetics as engineers reveal Nature’s unique capacities for the design and optimization of its products. Within this scope, significant work has been carried out by Prof. Claus Mattheck, director of the Research Center at Karlsruhe. Mattheck embarked on the mission of simulating knot healing processes in trees. Knots are usually attributed to dormant buds or cut side branches and are generally considered as imperfections in the wood which greatly affect its mechanical properties. Taking an in inspiration from Nature, Mattheck’s aim was to develop processes to mimic growth and refinement and further implement them as computational routines in the field of shape optimization.”For one of the four paragraphs in question, Business Insider claims that I incorrectly attributed the cited paragraph to two papers by different authors: “Vincent, J. F. V., Structural biomaterials,” Macmillan, London, 1982 and Vogel, S., “Comparative biomechanics: life’s physical world,” Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ. 2003.Business Insider claims the proper source for this paragraph is: "The mechanical properties of natural materials," by Michael Farries Ashby, L. J. Gibson, U Wegst and R Olive, published in 1995 in the Proceedings of the Royal Society of London.Ashby et al also cite Vincent and Vogel in their introductory paragraph just prior to the paragraph in question, as well as in their bibliography. I believe, therefore, that Ashby may also be using Vincent and Vogel in the paragraph in question, but clearly, since one of the sources I cite is from Vogel 2003, there is a problem with the citation.Unfortunately, because some of the original sources are not online, and Business Insider was unwilling to give me beyond 4pm to review these citations, I cannot confirm whether Business Insider or the sources I referenced for this paragraph are correct.When I obtain access to the original sources, I will check all of the above citations and request that MIT make any necessary corrections.As I have dedicated my career to advancing science and innovation, I have always recognized the profound importance of the contributions of my peers and those who came before me. I hope that my work is helpful to the generations to come.I am also incredibly grateful for the 15 years I spent at MIT beginning when I enrolled in the PhD program in 2005, obtained my PhD in 2010, and later joined the faculty that same year. I became a tenured member of the faculty in 2017 and then left MIT in 2020 after I got married, became a mother, and moved to New York City.I have continued my work in a new company I founded in New York City called OXMAN, which along with 27 other members of my team, we are working to advance innovation in product, architectural, and urban design. OXMAN has been in stealth mode. I look forward to sharing more about OXMAN later this year.
